direction.raw_text: rounds of ammo in the whole town! How do we fight them with that?! The Postman watches the Holnists prepare for attack.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You don't. Negotiate a settlement. Give them extra supplies. The men look at each other.   Sounds reasonable enough.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay. You're a government rep. You go tell them. The look on The Postman's face says it all.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 60   EXT. GATES (BENNING, OREGON) - DAY                              60 They open enough to let the Postman ride out, then close behind him. He sits nervously on his horse waving a white flag. He's met, dismounts and is led to a command post where Bethlehem is studying a rough map of the town.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Make it quick.     I've got an attack to coordinate.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: General, um, they've asked me to negotiate a peace treaty. The last time he and Bethlehem were face-to-face, the Postman had a shaved head, was dressed in rags, and was covered with cuts and bruises. Bethlehem can't place him, but there's something familiar all the same.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do I know you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't think so, sir. I -- BETHLEHEM (scans uniform) You're the Postman, aren't you? ABBY watches from the flap of Bethlehem's tent.    The guard sees and shoves her back inside. BETHLEHEM AND THE POSTMAN Bethlehem flicks at the uniform flag shoulder patch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The restored United States. Do these people really believe that shit? Who are you really? Although he wants to confess everything, something tells The Postman he has to try to brass it out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am a United States Postman. Authorized by order 417 of the restored Congress to -- (CONTINUED) 69. 60   CONTINUED:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was at the Battle of Georgetown. I watched the White House burn to the ground. Don't try to sell me on any restored U.S...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The new capital is based in Minneapolis. Inside the Hubert Humphrey Metrodome. You know, where the Vikings used to play?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're funny.    Now, what are the terms?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They'll open the gate and give you double what they usually give. Just don't hurt anybody. This was all a misunderstanding. Bethlehem thinks this over. 61   INT. ABBY'S TENT - DAY                                             61 Abby tracks the guard's silhouette through the canvas. Her eyes search the tent -- land on the cot in the corner and focus on its heavy, wooden legs. 62   EXT. GATES - DAY                                                   62 Bethlehem has decided.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Appreciate your offer, Postman. Problem is, you're in no position to negotiate. These people made it through the bugs and the riots and the three year winter. But they're not going to survive you. Bethlehem looks to Getty and nods.      Getty motions to a gunner. The MONSTER GUN is FIRED.       Just as a SHELL EXPLODES against the gates -- 63   INT. ABBY'S TENT - DAY                                             63 Abby brings the heavy wooden cot leg down on the unsuspecting guard's head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 64   EXT. CITY GATES - DAY                                          64 The cavalry ride through roiling smoke into the open town. Horrified, The Postman steps forward, but rifles are on him. All he can do is watch. The Mayor is the first to go down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Law six, justice can be dictated. (to soldiers) Kill him. And kill the restored United States with him. Bethlehem turns his attention to the battle.   A CAPTAIN steps forward with gun raised.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In accordance with law eight and by the authority of Emergency Order 46, you are hereby -- A CRACK of RIFLE FIRE. The Captain's forehead explodes and he falls to the ground. Shocked, Bethlehem whirls for the source of the GUNFIRE. Abby!   FIRING from a position behind a supply wagon. But even as Bethlehem turns, an ARROW SINGS in and lodges in his arm. Fired from a pocket of sentries up on the palisade. Bethlehem bellows in outrage and pain. The Postman takes advantage of the moment of chaos to grab the fallen Captain's gun. He pulls a Holnist rider from his horse and swings into the saddle. The unhorsed rider goes for his gun. But once more SHOTS RING OUT and he goes down. Bethlehem ducks as another BULLET ZINGS close.    Too close.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Get her. Two soldiers move forward. Suddenly The Postman's HORSE comes THUNDERING -- trampling the Holnist nearest him. The other Holnist hears, looks back, sees The Postman coming and takes aim just as The Postman brings his gun to bear. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 64   CONTINUED:                                                         64 The Holnist FIRES first. We don't see the hit. Just watch as The Postman FIRES an answering ROUND. The Holnist goes down. The Postman reins up alongside the wagon. Grunting with pain, he reaches down, takes Abby's arm and swings her up behind him. Then digs his heels in for all he's worth. More Holnists come on the run. They FIRE. The HORSE SNORTS in pain. He's hit. But The Postman urges him on, heading into the woods. Bethlehem snaps off the arrow shaft and shouts:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Colonel Getty! 65   EXT. WOODLAND ROAD - DAY                                           65 Abby is concerned as the horse slows to a trot.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We can't stop now. They'll be coming after us. The Postman's head lolls forward. She feels something on her hand, pulls it back smeared with blood. The Postman's shot in the belly. The horse is failing.       Near death. We hear the sound of PURSUING CAVALRY. Abby urges the horse off the road. When the thicket grows too dense, Abby jumps down. She catches The Postman as he slides off, easing him to the ground.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Abby... Abby shushes him. She pulls on the horse's bridle to force him farther along. But it's no good, the wounded horse goes down on its knees. And five RIDERS THUNDER past.       Fooled.   All but the SIXTH, who pulls up to listen. In the deep b.g., flames lick at the billowing black smoke. The town is burning. The HORSE WHINNIES: in its death throes.        Abby panics, tries to quiet the horse. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 65   CONTINUED:                                                    65 The Sixth Soldier has heard the suffering horse. He draws his rifle from the saddle boot and starts into the thicket. ON ABBY AND POSTMAN The Postman lies unconscious on the ground. Abby sits beside him, rifle in hand. The Sixth Soldier appears.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't move. He hesitates at first. Then dismounts and moves toward her. Abby cocks the rifle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If you'd had a bullet, you'd a used it by now. Moving closer still, he doesn't see the BRANCH pulled back in The Postman's hand until it SNAPS hard into his face. He stumbles back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're right. Abby dashes out, rifle in hand. She swings for the bleachers. The butt catches the side of the Sixth Soldier's head. He falls hard. The Postman's eyes flutter. Dazed, he watches as Abby pilfers through the Soldier's gear. She takes everything of value: a knife, bullets, a canteen. His eyes flutter closed. 66   EXT. WOODS - DAY                                              66 Snowflakes swirl. Abby lays a sapling travois beside The Postman. He groans as she rolls him onto it, tucks a blanket around him. Using all the strength God gave her, Abby lifts one end, gets it high enough to hitch it to the Sixth Soldier's horse. As Abby leads the horse away... 67   EXT. WOOD ROAD - DAY                                          67 The snow has increased. A Holnist patrol moves down the road, disappears around a bend. A beat. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 67   CONTINUED:                                                       67 Abby appears, leading the horse and travois.   She crosses the road and disappears into the woods. A moment later, she reappears with a pine branch which she uses to brush at the snow, obscuring their tracks. 68   EXT. CASCADE MOUNTAINS (OREGON) - DAY                            68 Riding into a blizzard, Abby leads the way up a zigzag path. A valley opens up below. The unconscious Postman lies bundled on the travois. 69   EXT. HUNTING SHACK - DUSK                                        69 A little square shape just visible beyond a creek.     Abby leads the horse and travois-bound Postman to it. 70   INT. HUNTING SHACK - DUSK                                        70 One room. Dirt floor. The WINDOWS RATTLE in the WIND. Snow falls through a hole in the roof. The wooden DOOR BURSTS back and Abby enters. Half-frozen, she leads the horse and the travois right inside. 71   INT. HUNTING SHACK - NIGHT                                       71 A fire has been lit. The Postman lies unconscious, his shirt open as Abby washes around his wound. She pulls the shirt back to clean his chest. The material falls away and Abby stops short. There -- high on his biceps -- a branded "8." She stares in disbelief. DISSOLVE TO: 72   INT. HUNTING SHACK - DAY                                         72 The Postman lies on a cot below the window.    He's conscious, but pale as a ghost. Abby brings him a bowl of soup. Very thin soup.       Stirring it with a spoon, The Postman smiles at Abby.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you. She turns her back on him without a word.   The Postman tries an exchange just the same. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 72   CONTINUED:                                                      72 THE POSTMAN I don't think I ever had water soup before. Maybe next time we could try it with a little sand? (as she doesn't respond) Dirt? Wood? (as she doesn't smile) A twig garnish? She goes about her business in silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You used to think I was funny.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They killed Michael.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry. He takes a spoonful of soup and she comes to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How sorry are you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's that supposed to mean? Her right hand flashes out, holds a knife up under his chin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's with you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You got the mark of eight on you. A long beat. Finally, he swallows the soup in his mouth. The action presses his Adam's apple against the blade.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A mark doesn't mean I'm a -- ABBY You're a liar.     I should've let you die.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then, why didn't you? If she knows, she's not ready to say yet. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 72   CONTINUED:    (2)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You were with Bethlehem. Does that make you one of them? Abby considers this, The Postman's gaze flickers down to the spoon he still holds in his hand. Taking one last stab at a joke.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't make me use this. Abby doesn't laugh.      But she does relent.   She steps away. 73   EXT. HUNTING SHACK/VALLEY PASS - SUNSET                           73 The hunting shack huddled against the south side of a low rise. Beyond the rise, a pass. But there's no negotiating it now. It's completely snowed in. And another storm is on the way. 74   INT. HUNTING SHACK - DAY                                          74 WIND HOWLING in the b.g. The Postman lies back on his cot. The little shack has been scoured clean. Abby stares listlessly at the fire. The silence is torture. The Postman tries to strike up a conversation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wind's come up. (no response from Abby) Getting colder too. Must be another storm -- Abby gets up and throws a log on the fire.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anything else?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I didn't mean for you to -- ABBY Your legs are going to rot off if you don't try to walk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm hurt. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 74   CONTINUED:                                                      74 ABBY You're lazy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lazy?! I got a hole in my stomach. I'm weak. The two big meals around here are grass and snow. And we're running out of grass. As the two of them glare at each other for a moment.     Abby starts to put on her coat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where are you going? Abby doesn't answer. She picks up the rifle and starts to lead the horse outside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're not leaving me here, are you? Abby is out the door without a word. 75   EXT. HUNTING SHACK - DAY                                        75 HOLD ON The Postman in the window as she continues past. He watches a moment, suddenly grimaces. A GUNSHOT. The THUD of a BODY SLAMMING to the GROUND. Abby has shot the horse.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 76   EXT. HUNTING SHACK/PASS - SUNRISE                               76 Tiny tracks in the snow, leading away from the shack. Abby struggles to make the monumental climb from the shack to the top of the rise where she can get a clear view of the pass. PAN PAST her UP TO the top of the rise. It's a clear day -- but the pass is still snowed-in. No sign of winter receding. DISSOLVE TO: 77   INT. HUNTING SHACK - DAY                                        77 Abby ladles a meager portion of horse meat stew into a bowl. (CONTINUED) 77. 77   CONTINUED:                                                       77 ABBY This is the last of it. She walks with the bowl past The Postman -- who sits on his cot with arms outstretched -- and pointedly sets the bowl on the table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Give me a break... Abby starts putting on layer after layer of clothing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm going to check the pass.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why are you in such a hurry to get out of here? I can think of worse places. And worse company to -- And with the SLAM of the DOOR she is gone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 78   INT. HUNTING SHACK - DAY                                         78 A few flakes of snow have begun to drift down. The Postman sits at the window -- starts to play tic-tac-toe in the frost. But then it dawns on him:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You can't play tic-tac-toe with yourself. 79   EXT. WOODS - DAY                                                 79 Disoriented, Abby stops to take stock of her surround- ings. But she can't make anything out -- the snowfall is too thick. 80   INT. HUNTING SHACK - DAY                                         80 The fire is dying. The food untouched. The Postman sits in bed staring anxiously out the window. The snow has turned into a blizzard. He runs Abby's red ribbon through his hands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 81   EXT. WOODS - DAY                                             81 Abby trudges along heavily. She stumbles as the ice covering the stream breaks beneath her feet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Help! 82   INT. HUNTING SHACK - DAY                                     82 The Postman hears her call. 83   EXT. HUNTING SHACK - DAY                                     83 The door opens and out steps The Postman. In pain, he staggers around the back of the cabin -- in search of her. 84   EXT. STREAM - DAY                                            84 Abby looks up, sees him coming. The Postman collapses across from her. Both prone, they're also nearly nose-to- nose.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can't help you. Finally, he pulls himself to his knees. She does the same. They climb each other to a standing position. Arm- in-arm, they start for the cabin. 85   INT. HUNTING SHACK - DUSK                                    85 Abby sits huddled in blankets. The fire is blazing. The Postman steps over, sets the once-again-hot bowl of stew before her. She considers the food a moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I told you that's all there was.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's why you should have it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I knew you could walk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're weird, you know that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 86   INT. HUNTING SHACK - NIGHT                                    86 The Postman lies in bed, stares through the hole in the roof. A full moon is on the rise. Abby lies in her own makeshift bed, also awake. After a long silence:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We walked on the moon once, Abby.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So?    What good is that now?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Obviously you've forgotten Tang and microwave ovens. (a beat) Your face looks pretty. Abby looks up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not so bruised.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look, there's something you'd better know. You're going to find out soon enough. I'm pregnant. (a long beat) It's Michael's baby. You're just the body father.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How do you know it's mine and not Bethlehem's?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He tried with me almost every night. He couldn't do it. So he beat me. Said it was my fault.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 87   EXT. HUNTING SHACK/PASS - DAY                                 87 Abby stands atop the low rise -- looking out to the pass. Spring has come to the mountains. At long last the snow is starting to recede. DISSOLVE TO: 88   EXT. FISHING POOL - DAY                                       88 The Postman kneels by the bank, sharpening a knife to clean the fish he's caught. (CONTINUED) 80. 88   CONTINUED:                                                          88 Then, he catches his reflection in the water.       Tangled beard. Matted hair. Is that him? He suddenly starts sharpening the knife with renewed vigor. We get a sense he's not going to use it on the fish. HANDS plunge into the water, pull splashfuls up. We START ON The Postman's back, then ARC AROUND as he washes his face. He's just finished shaving off his beard with the hunting knife. He's nicked-up, but it's a definite improvement and he smiles in satisfaction -- until he sees -- Abby, reflected in the water.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Abby. The Postman whips around to see her standing there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What is it?   What's wrong?    Is it the baby?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The pass is clear. It's time to go. Behind her, he sees the cabin is on fire.       Takes off running. 89   EXT. HUNTING SHACK - DAY                                            89 The fire is blazing. The hunting shack is too far gone to save. The Postman turns around.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What happened? He's nonplused to find Abby standing beside a pile of their neatly-packed gear.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You got our stuff out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 89   CONTINUED:                                                      89 THE POSTMAN Of course?   I don't understand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I set the fire.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Am I missing the point here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You didn't think we'd stay here forever, did you? (The Postman has no response) I'd appreciate if you'd walk with me long enough to find someplace safe for the baby. Then we can split up. (a beat) You shaved. The Postman has all but forgotten.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It looks nice. Before he can respond, she's heading off toward the pass, leaving The Postman to shake his head at the absurdity of it all. He shouts after her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're really weird, you know that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 90   EXT. VALLEY - BELOW CASCADE MOUNTAINS - DAY                     90 Carrying their gear, Abby and The Postman walk across a meadow of wild flowers, headed for an old road.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Have you ever heard of St. Rose, Abby?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've heard people talk. I've heard lots of names. Bliss. Hesperia. New Eden. Sheriff Briscoe says it's a fantasy. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 90   CONTINUED:                                                    90 THE POSTMAN He's wrong. St. Rose is out there. And I'm going to find it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But you're The Postman.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look, I'm nobody, Abby. I'm just... Before he can come clean -- they see a distant RIDER coming hard. The Postman unslings the rifle, slides a round into the chamber.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is what I hate. Strangers. Do you say 'hi' or do you blow their head off? Do they want to share what they got or take what you have? And if they want to take, how far are you willing to go to stop them? Damn it. (to the Rider) All right. That's far enough. The Rider pulls up short, wearing a blue home-made uniform.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We don't want any trouble.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Me neither, mister. The Postman is taken aback. The Rider, a girl, pulls off her cap, mops it across her brow. Maybe 14, we'll always know her by her Ponytail. Abby registers the uniform first.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What are you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Carrier 18. U.S. Postal Service. Got any mail? Lowering the rifle, The Postman looks over at Abby, back to Ponytail.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's impossible. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 90   CONTINUED:    (2)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ain't you heard of The Postman?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, tell us.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's only the greatest man who ever lived. He crossed the wasteland, shook his fist at the enemy and spit in the eye of General Bethlehem himself. He's back east with President Starkey right now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who told you all this?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Postmaster Ford Lincoln Mercury. He's in direct contact with the restored congress.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Direct contact... I don't believe this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you have mail, or don't you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You said Carrier Eighteen. That mean there's eighteen of you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thirty-two.    As of midnight. 91   EXT. R.V. PARK - DAY                                           91 Oregon's main post office. A silver Airstream, fifty mobile homes and rusty Winnebagos resting on flat tires. Flying from a pole: the flag of the restored United States. A young recruit is ringing a bell on the top of a Winnebago. Ford walks along an RV boulevard. He's joined by two young carriers, RED and Chubby (the sentry from Benning). All wear hip, personalized variations of the official uniform.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You got another letter? (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 91   CONTINUED:                                                     91 They come around the corner to where seven young recruits wait. They're joined by another twenty carriers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: More recruits?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Seven of them. They're coming from everywhere. Ford looks them over in satisfaction.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did you get a letter or didn't you? Ford smiles, reaches into his pocket. He pulls out a creased sheet of paper. Chubby grins.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gather 'round, everybody. Got another letter here. Came in last night. Buzzing with excitement, the carriers gather around Ford. SOUTH END OF BOULEVARD Ponytail leads Abby and The Postman. They come up in the back of the crowd. Flanked by Red and Chubby, Ford stands on the hood of a car, letter in hand. The Postman taps a clueless YOUNG CARRIER on the back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's all this?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Postman sent Ford another letter. He's gonna read it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 'Hello, all postal carriers.'
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello! (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 91   CONTINUED:    (2)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm here in Minneapolis with President Starkey, but my thoughts are with you. Remember, nothing worth doing can be done overnight. Keep your chins up and do your best not to get shot. Signed, The Postman. A buzz goes through the crowd.       Ponytail looks over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His letters are always kind of short. Abby and The Postman exchange a look.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hold on now. There's a P.S... Anybody know what P.S. stands for? The Postman raises his hand. Ford looks his way. His mouth drops as he realizes. In silence, he walks over to The Postman. They embrace and all the weight Ford's been carrying on his young shoulders suddenly falls to The Postman. The kid nearly collapses.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Holy shit...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That would be H.S., Chubby.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I seen him once when I lived in Benning. It's The Postman! Word goes through the crowd like a wave. The Postman takes the letter, reads.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .S.   Ford knows what to do. Ford shrugs sheepishly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Guess you want to talk about this? The Postman takes Ford by the elbow. They disappear into the tent. The carriers just staring after them, awestruck. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 91   CONTINUED:    (3)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I found him!   I found him! They clamor around her. 92   INT. TENT - DAY                                                 92 The Postman and Ford.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: President Starkey? Minneapolis? Ford knows what to do?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I thought you were dead.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So? I'm not making the connection. What's all this then?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I lied. I told people you were in contact with me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Because I didn't want it to end.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know how long I can stay, Ford. President Starkey will send word one day and I'll have to move on. Understand?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sure. But you'll stay till he sends word? Right? The Postman can't answer, just turns and walks out of the tent. 93   EXT. TENT - DAY                                                 93 As The Postman exits, Chubby leads the carriers in a salute. The Postman actually turns a moment to see if someone else is standing behind him. He looks back, sees the young, shining faces. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 93   CONTINUED:                                                         93 THE POSTMAN Aw, don't do that. Hands down. Their hands go down in one crisp military move. The Postman looks at Abby, to Ford as he exits the tent.         The kid is craving reassurance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You'll stay 'til President Starkey sends word, right? Right?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, till he sends word, right. Ford smiles, gestures to the carriers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Could you say a few words? The Postman looks over at the carriers.    They quiet under his gaze, immediately respectful. The problem is, he has no idea what to say.       Finally:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Two plus two equals four. The cheering is tumultuous. The Postman picks Abby out of the cheering crowd -- the look on her face says it all. 94   EXT. RV PARK - WINNEBAGO ROW - DAY                                 94 The guts of the operation. Several carriers are busy sorting and bagging letters. It goes out pinned to a clothesline which crisscrosses back and forth. Everyone follows as Ford takes The Postman on a tour. There are hushed whispers among those who are seeing him for the first time.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We bring all the mail here first. We sort it, group it and then it goes out. So far we got thirty routes. Ford leads The Postman and Abby into another Winnebago. Chubby and Red and Ponytail follow. Those that can't fit just peer in through the windows.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 95   INT. WINNEBAGO - DAY                                         95 An old manual crank printing press is working away. Ford proudly removes a sheet, shows it to The Postman. A caricature of eight evil Holnists, forming a figure eight. Beneath: "Unite Against Holnist Tyrraney!"
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You spelled tyranny wrong.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Boy, he's smart. 96   EXT. RV CAMP - GREEN LAWN - DAY                              96 The seven young Recruits seen earlier stand in a line. They're joined by OLD GEORGE, every day of 75 years old. Ponytail holds up her hand, swears them in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Neither snow, nor rain, nor heat, nor gloom of night... As they finish, The Postman and Ford pass by. The Recruits salute. Shaking his head, The Postman's about to salute back when he spots Old George. George has a faded purple "AIRBORNE" tattoo on his arm and a twinkle in his eye. There's an old crow on his shoulder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How old are you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Seventy-five, sir. The Postman looks over at Ford, who shrugs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can you ride?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nope. Can't walk too good, either.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why are you here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know stuff. The Postman looks at Ford again.   Then: (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 96   CONTINUED:                                                      96 THE POSTMAN (re: tattoo) When did you get that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . A girl with eyes as big as saucers did me in a little town called Saigon. 97   EXT. RV CAMP - AIRSTREAM - SUNSET                               97 Carriers move items out of the trailer. The camp is buzzing as usual. The Postman looks on -- sees Abby passing by.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Abby -- ABBY Yes? He's got her attention, just doesn't know what to do with it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ford wants me to have his trailer. Said it's the best one.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm on the other side of town.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I got plenty of room here. She shakes her head, and then walks away. The Postman watches her disappear into the bustle of the camp.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So much for the uniform theory. 98   EXT. HOLNIST WINTER CAMP (NORTHERN CALIFORNIA) - SUNSET         98 The same sun sets on the Holnist camp. 99   INT. BETHLEHEM'S TENT - SUNSET                                  99 Bethlehem once again at his easel with palette in hand. He's trying another style -- Impressionism -- and it's worse than the last. He looks over as Getty and Gibbs approach with a PRISONER. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 99   CONTINUED:                                                     99 BETHLEHEM What do you think, Lieutenant?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can't tell what it is if you stand too close. The colors all kinda run together, don't they?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes... Bethlehem looks away from his painting to see Gibbs and Getty flanking a scared, blue-clad mail carrier. For an instant, mistakes him for:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, if it isn't our old friend the U.P.S. man.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We captured him on the Oregon border. Realizing, Bethlehem turns the face from side-to-side.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who the hell are you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Carrier Twelve. United States, um, Postal Service. Getty sets some of the Carrier's anti-Holnist propaganda onto Bethlehem's field table. Bethlehem picks it up. It's hard to say what he's thinking.      Finally:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I want the camp struck at dawn. We're moving north.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, sir. Bethlehem looks back to Carrier Twelve.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You spelled tyranny wrong.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 100   EXT. RV CAMP - DAWN                                           100 Ten letter carriers are on horseback. Among them, Red and Ponytail. Ford and The Postman are also on horses. Each rider salutes The Postman, then gets a sheaf of anti- Holnist propaganda from Ford.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I wish they'd stop saluting. It's annoying him. As Chubby rides up. The Postman catches his right wrist as he attempts to salute. So Chubby salutes with the left hand instead. As they line up:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just stay safe and remember. The mailman's more important than the mail.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Boy, he's smart. The sun just peeks up over the horizon. At that signal, the carriers thunder off, the ground trembling under them. The look on their faces. The glory of it all. They're alive! The Postman hesitates, watches after them a moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What the hell? Urging his horse forward, he rides after them. With them. And then, like an exploding firework, each postman shoots off in a separate direction. Headed for all points of the compass and some in between. 101   EXT. OREGON HAMLET - DAY                                      101 The Postman looks down on the gathered crowd from his horse and smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For President Starkey and the First Congress of the Restored United States, I officially declare Postal Station 10... What's the name of this town?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We never named it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I officially declare Postal Station 10 in Elvis, Oregon, open for business!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 102   EXT. TOWN (SOMEWHERE IN OREGON) - DAY                         102 An eye-blink of a town. Ponytail stands on a crate reading names and handing letters to the grateful people massed around her. 103   EXT. TOWN (IDAHO BORDER) - DAY                                103 Red and Chubby finish mail call, exchange an amazed look as they're offered a platter of food. 104   EXT. HIGHWAY - NIGHT                                          104 The moon hangs low over an interstate. A rider is silhouetted by the silvery orb, looking like some post- apocalyptic Don Quixote. It's The Postman. 105   EXT. FARMHOUSE/COUNTRY ROAD - DAY                             105 Seen FROM the porch, a rider gallops hard on the road beyond. A LITTLE BOY comes rushing out, letter in hand. The boy pulls up short; realizes the rider is already too far gone. The boy's shoulders sag; he's crushed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I missed him. It's an almost psychic moment as the rider reins up in the distance and turns back around. A frozen beat and he starts galloping back down the road. Fearless, the boy holds out the letter. The rider closes; it's The Postman. The boy stretches out as far as he can. Without breaking stride, The Postman leans out of the saddle, snatches the letter as he passes. The boy watches after him -- knows what he's going to be when he grows up. 106   EXT. PINE VIEW GATES - DAY                                    106 Sheriff Briscoe huffs and puffs his big frame up the ladder and onto the top of the palisade.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Phil, this better not be another of your U.F.O.'s. He looks where the sentry points. The Postman waits at the gate, behind him on horseback: Ford and Abby. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 106   CONTINUED:                                                      106 THE POSTMAN I'm back!   And I got mail.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll be damned. 107   EXT. PINE VIEW STREETS - DAY                                    107 The Postman rides with Briscoe, hurrying to stay alongside him. Half the town jogs along behind them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bethlehem is offering a 1000 pounds of gold to whoever brings you in. Dead or alive.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank God it wasn't a carton of cigarettes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'd have shot you myself. 108   EXT. PINE VIEW STREETS - NIGHT                                  108 Pine View is throwing a party. It's in full swing. A couple of guitars. A banjo and a trombone. Everyone dances. The Postman walks with Briscoe, sees Mrs. March as her letter is read to her. Catches a glimpse of Abby dancing with Ford. He seems, for the first time, truly happy. For that matter, so does Briscoe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Things are getting better. Getting better all the time. (a beat) I don't know who you are, but I do know I was wrong about you. The Postman smiles, reaches in his bag for an envelope.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Got a letter for you, Sheriff. Briscoe turns it over in his hands, looks up in wonder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's from my sister. I thought she was dead. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 108   CONTINUED:                                                     108 THE POSTMAN You thought wrong. Briscoe has tears in his eyes.    The Postman continues on, embarrassed but affected. DANCE The Postman taps Ford's shoulder, wants to cut in on him and Abby. Ford steps aside. A beat before Abby decides it's okay. They begin. Her eyes are on her feet, careful that she doesn't take a misstep. But his eyes are on her. And over it all, BLEEDING IN, the sound of HOOF BEATS. 109   EXT. LONELY ROAD (SOUTHERN OREGON) - NIGHT                     109 A mail carrier, Red, rides like the devil himself was in pursuit. Almost. It's Getty and three Holnists. INTERCUT WITH: DANCE They whirl as the tempo picks up. The Postman pulls Abby in closer. Her eyes now move up to his. ROAD They're closing in on the terrified Red. DANCE Abby and The Postman.    The chemistry is undeniable. ROAD RIFLES CRACK. SHOT in the back, Red throws back his arms. Letters flutter from the mail bag over his shoulder; he seems to glide along that way forever. DANCE The Postman looks at Abby; she's so beautiful.    Like only a pregnant woman can be. (CONTINUED) 95. 109   CONTINUED:    (2)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tell me about the baby, Abby.   I want to know. Abby snaps out of the dream she's in. This isn't right. Breaking away, she heads off. As he watches her go: ROAD Red falls from his horse.    One of the soldiers scoops up his mailbag.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 110   INT. COMMAND TENT (SOUTHERN OREGON) - NIGHT                       110 By lantern, Bethlehem and Getty watch as Gibbs sorts through the contents of the confiscated mailbag.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Births and deaths, the weather, gossip. There's nothing here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nothing? Everything is here.    Am I the only one who sees that? (to Gibbs) Get out! Gibbs hurries away, leaving Bethlehem and Getty alone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Give the people back their hope and their dreams won't be far behind. Bethlehem sees Getty waiting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What is it, Getty? Getty hands Bethlehem a sheet of paper -- something Gibbs missed. It's a propaganda sheet featuring a caricature of The Postman leading a few carriers against Bethlehem and his army -- represented as Hitler and the Nazis. The caption underneath reads: "Ride Against the Holnist Tide!" (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 110   CONTINUED:                                                      110 BETHLEHEM (crumpling the paper) A military man, especially a commander, should keep a journal. After he's gone, it's the only real defense against the slander that arises. 111   INT. OLD GEORGE'S TRAILER - NIGHT                               111 Old George sits hunched over a home-made shortwave radio with a joint in his mouth. The Postman sits beside him, listening as STATIC pours from an old car SPEAKER.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who do you talk to?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not a soul in seven years of trying. But I will. The Postman steps to a telescope pointing up through a hole in the trailer ceiling.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Go ahead. Take a look. (offering joint) Want some?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. No thanks. Hey, don't let the kids see that. George nods and goes on playing with the dials -- searching for a voice in the void. The Postman focuses on the moon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was an aerospace engineer. I helped design the Galileo space station. (scanning sky) I dream it's orbiting Earth forever. With a dozen human skeletons all grinning at each other. Laughing at us down here. There's an urgent KNOCKING on the trailer door.    Ford appears.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What is it? (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 111   CONTINUED:                                                   111 FORD It's Red.   He's overdue.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That makes five. All on Southern routes. 112   EXT. TRUCK STOP - DAY                                        112 Five dead mail carriers have been laid out on the asphalt. Bethlehem walks the line, looking for his elusive arch- enemy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.  No. Not him. No. (looks to soldiers) Children. I want a man and you bring me children! 113   EXT. OREGON ROAD - DAY                                       113 A beautiful day. Ponytail rounds a bend at a lope -- and then -- her eyes widen in terror. She jerks the reins; the horse rears in protest. Ahead: the truck stop. The five mail carriers hang upside down from the roof's overhang. A macabre sight. POV THROUGH RIFLE SCOPE SIGHTING ON Ponytail. A hand comes INTO FRAME and brings the rifle barrel down. It's -- GIBBS AND HOLNIST SHARPSHOOTER GIBBS Not yet. General wants the message to get back. 114   EXT. RV. CAMP - NIGHT                                        114 PAN UP FROM The Postman's dusty boots TO his grimly determined face as he strides through camp and stops at Old George's trailer. He moves OUT OF FRAME, revealing -- Abby and Ponytail in the b.g.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 115   INT. OLD GEORGE'S TRAILER - NIGHT                               115 As usual, Old George is hunkered down before his short wave. He looks as the door opens and The Postman enters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tell me about the other stuff you know... George crosses the trailer, opens a cabinet. Inside: twenty odd guns plus the parts for several more. The CROW CAWS. 116   EXT. ELVIS, OREGON - DAY                                        116 Quiet. An old flag ruffles outside the post office -- the only new structure in town. Old George sweeps the porch as a patrol of ten Holnist soldiers ride into town. George makes no move to flee as they near. As they rein up across from him he just smiles and continues sweeping. Sensing it, the Holnist officer looks up. There, on the roof, stands The Postman. Ford and Briscoe flank him -- along with twenty mailmen and locals, armed with guns, bows and rocks. As the soldiers raise their rifles, the roofies OPEN FIRE. George whips up a sawed-off SHOTGUN. BOOM! Caught in the storm, the ten soldiers go down. Grim, The Postman looks to Ford as the locals cheer. George resumes sweeping. The mailmen climb down to strip the weapons off the dead.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ford, I want you to get rid of the bodies. I don't want these people blamed for what we did. Ford nods. 117   EXT. HOLNIST ARMY CAMP - NIGHT                                  117 Two sentries guard the east. They peer into the gloom at the sound of a WAGON APPROACHING. It sounds like it's coming fast.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Halt!   Identify yourself! (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 117   CONTINUED:                                                     117 WAGON tearing along. Ford at the reins, urging the horses to all possible speed.  Then he stands, leaps to the ground. SENTRIES They raise their rifles as the riderless wagon looms out of the night. They each get off a SHOT before being forced to dive out of the way. The wagon continues on, down to... HOLNIST CAMP A soldier finally grabs hold of one of the halters and brings the wagon to a stop. Half-dressed, Bethlehem steps up. A tarp covers the back upon which is written...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Postage due... Bethlehem yanks away the tarp to reveal the 10 dead Holnist soldiers. The men around Bethlehem exchange looks, can't believe it. Bethlehem bellows in rage. 118   EXT. WOODS - NIGHT                                             118 Ford, hidden in the woods, smiles at the sound. 119   EXT. HOLNIST CAMP - NIGHT                                      119 Bethlehem steps forward and shouts his challenge into the night.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You want a war? I'll give you a war. I was born for it! 120   EXT. WOODS - NIGHT                                             120 Bethlehem's words reach Ford, his smile fades. He's just a scared boy. He kicks his horse into a gallop and rides away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 100. 121   EXT. SMALL AIRFIELD - DAY                                    121 In the fog, the sound of hollow HOOF BEATS. The Postman rides past the shapes of airplanes. Standing silent. Forever grounded. The ghosts of the past. 122   EXT. RV CAMP - DAY                                           122 Ford is swearing in four new recruits. ON FORD AND RECRUITS As they repeat after him we realize they've changed the oath a bit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Neither snow, nor heat, nor gloom of night. Through bandit's hell, through fire fight. Through flood and plague we cannot fail. No Holnist trash will stop the mail. THE POSTMAN riding his weary mount into town, saddlebags bulging with mail. He pauses by the new recruits long enough to hear the words they're saying. As he dismounts, a fresh-faced carrier takes the bridle. The Postman's well past the point of fatigue. He's living on pure adrenaline.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Get this mail sorted. Bring me a fresh horse. Something to eat. As fresh-face starts away, The Postman calls after him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And all the mail going South! The Postman watches as Ford shakes the hands of the new recruits. The Postman reaches for his canteen. Empty. Damn. A tin cup filled with water appears from nowhere. Abby. The Postman takes it, too tired to acknowledge the gesture.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They changed the oath. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 122   CONTINUED:                                                       122 ABBY Ford's idea.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Figures. (scoffs) They don't think to ask who they're replacing. Or why. He drains the cup and hands it back to her.      Just then, one of the new recruits, LUKE, steps over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sir? It'd be an honor if I could shake your hand. A farmboy-type, Luke looks like a younger version of Woody. The Postman sees this, is lost in reverie. Luke still holds his hand out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sir?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You look like... Do I know you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, sir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, good luck to you. Nodding in awe, Luke heads off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nice kid.   Probably be dead in a week.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're exhausted. You need rest. There's food in the trailer -- Ponytail rides by; two sacks of mail hang from her saddle pommel. The Postman grabs her horse's halter, stops her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where are you going?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Route twenty-two. I'm already an hour late. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 122   CONTINUED:    (2)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're grounded. Get off the horse. You know the rule.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What rule?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Twenty-two's too far south.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But they're waiting on their mail down there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Get off the goddamn horse. Shocked, she does. At the same time, fresh-face comes up leading a second horse laden with mail.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tie him off to this one. Fresh-face goes about tying the second horse to the first.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You can't keep doing this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Doing what?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Riding all the routes.   You're not saving anyone. The Postman climbs on Ponytail's horse, looks at Abby.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did I ever tell you how I got to be a postman, Abby? (doesn't give her time to answer) I don't know if you'd laugh or cry. The Postman digs in his heels. The horse gallops away, the second one following behind.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 123   EXT. ELVIS, OREGON - CLOSE ON BLOODIED POSTAL CARRIER -         123 NIGHT A crowd of townsfolk are visible in deep b.g.   Beyond them, the town of Elvis burns to the ground. The CAMERA CIRCLES AROUND the BLOODIED CARRIER until we're looking OVER his shoulder at a firing squad led by Colonel Getty and Lieutenant Gibbs. Bethlehem watches.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ready! The only building not on fire is the post office. A SOLDIER rides up, carrying a torch, meaning to burn it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The post office, General?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. Let it stand. All by itself. So it can remind them what it cost them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Aim! Rifles are aimed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fire! Shock and dismay from the townsfolk as SHOTS RING OUT. CLOSE ON BLOODY CARRIER'S FACE as he realizes he's still standing. PULL BACK to reveal nine bodies lying on the ground.     Only the Bloodied Carrier is still standing. Bethlehem points at the Bloodied Carrier, crooks a finger for him. He staggers up. Bethlehem smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You think you can ride? (as the Carrier nods) Then today's your lucky day. 124   INT. RV PARK - AIRSTREAM - DAY                                  124 Abby tends to the Bloodied Carrier.   He tries to salute as The Postman enters the trailer. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 124   CONTINUED:                                                       124 Ford and Chubby watch and wait as The Postman goes to the boy's side.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bethlehem says... The Postman motions it's okay as the Carrier struggles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... he's... headed north. He's gonna kill ten people in every town. Then burn it to the ground. For what you did... The Postman is puzzled.    But Ford knows what and why.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He said to tell you Pine View's on his way. He said he'd wait there, but not for long. (breaking down) I was so scared, sir... I thought they were going to kill me, too... I wish they would have... 125   EXT. RISE ABOVE PINE VIEW - DAY                                  125 The Postman poised on a rise that affords a view of the gruesome spectacle below. POSTMAN'S POV Pine View in flames. The big John Deere gun has blown several gaps into the palisade. Bethlehem watches as his army sacks the town. The people have been rounded up. The selection of the ten has begun. 126   EXT. RISE ABOVE PINE VIEW - DAY                                  126 The Postman wheels his horse around. But Ford, Ponytail, Chubby and Luke are standing in his way.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What are you going to do?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm going to stop this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You can't. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 126   CONTINUED:                                                        126 THE POSTMAN Get out of my way, Ford. All of you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They'll kill you. The Postman starts to ride through them.      Luke, Chubby and Ponytail move their horses to block. Ford maneuvers his horse in close and grabs The Postman's harness.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Goddamnit -- The Postman jumps off his horse. Ford tackles him. The Postman shoves him away, continues on. Luke and Chubby pounce on him. With Ford's help, they hold him down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You can't help them!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's still time, Ford! The Postman struggles.      They're genuinely having trouble holding him down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're hurting him. But there's no let-up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, this is all my doing.    I went against your orders. There's a moment of shocked surprise.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Holnists we killed. You told me to bury them. But I didn't. I sent Bethlehem the bodies.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Because Bethlehem has to know that we're not going to stop. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 126   CONTINUED:    (2)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: God damn you, Ford. Those people down there are dying because of us. Because of what we did.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bullshit. They're dying because of Bethlehem. They're dying because this is a shitty world. And if we're ever going to change it, then somebody might have to die. If I could make it be me down there I would. But I can't. A terrible SCREAM gives them all pause. 127   EXT. PINE VIEW - DAY                                             127 Down below -- Holnist soldiers hold back a screaming mother as her 10-year-old boy is pulled into the line. Sheriff Briscoe is among the ten, he puts his hand on the boy's shoulder -- the picture of grace under pressure. 128   EXT. RISE ABOVE PINE VIEW - ON POSTMAN AND CARRIERS              128 THE POSTMAN My God, what have I done? (beat) We don't even know their names... 129   EXT. PINE VIEW - CLOSE ON LITTLE BOY - DAY                       129 His eyes wide and fearful.    Like a kitten's. 130   EXT. RISE ABOVE PINE VIEW - DAY                                  130 PONYTAIL (holding back the tears) We know their names. The little one's my brother. His name is Billy. A moment of stunned silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What Ford did was wrong. But it doesn't change anything for any of us. Does it? (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 130   CONTINUED:                                                        130 She looks to the other carriers -- it's written all over their faces -- they stand with Ponytail and Ford. 131   EXT. PINE VIEW - DAY                                              131 Bethlehem looks the line-up over. The firing squad stands at the ready. Bethlehem looks to the trees -- feeling something.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's out there somewhere. Watching. I can feel it. Briscoe follows his gaze. He doesn't see anything, but maybe gets the same feeling. Bethlehem looks to Briscoe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You feel it too, don't you? Didn't have to end like this, Sheriff. He knew where I'd be if he wanted to face me like a man. Instead, he's hiding like a rabbit. So much for your Postman.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ready!    Aim! Rifles are raised. Briscoe seems to grow as he throws his shoulders back and shouts...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ride, Postman! Ride! You hear me? I said ride! 132   EXT. RISE ABOVE PINE VIEW - DAY                                   132 The WORDS ECHO.       Nothing The Postman can do, but watch. 133   EXT. PINE VIEW - DAY                                              133 Bethlehem's eyes go wild -- BETHLEHEM Fire! The RIFLES BARK.      Everyone falls dead. 134   EXT. RISE ABOVE PINE VIEW - DAY                                   134 Something in The Postman breaks. He just lies there.       The witnesses move back, taking The Postman with them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 135   EXT. PINE VIEW - DAY                                             135 Sheriff Briscoe lies dead.   The letter from his sister blows from his hand. CUT TO: 136   INT. AIRSTREAM - NIGHT                                           136 The Postman folds a letter, shoves it into an envelope. He writes "Bethlehem" across the front, starts to write a second letter. The door opens and Abby enters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ford thinks you're going to do something.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am. The Postman watches as, outside, the mail carriers begin to assemble.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If I don't, those kids are going to keep on getting themselves killed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ford doesn't know what it means to be a kid. He doesn't have your memories. None of them do. All they've got is the lousy world we gave them. And this is the only decent thing in it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What? Being a postman? It's all bullshit, Abby. All of it. (beat) I took this uniform off a skeleton to stay warm. I made up the rest to stay fed. There is no restored United States.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I knew it was something like that. The Postman fingers the brim of the cap, softens. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 136   CONTINUED:                                                      136 THE POSTMAN Weird thing is, being a Postman was almost the best thing that ever happened to me... (re: red ribbon) Remember this? You left it behind that night.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I remember...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I always liked to think you left it on purpose. But maybe you just forgot it. Abby doesn't answer.    She leaves instead. 137   EXT. R.V. CAMP - NIGHT                                          137 Twelve mail carriers, including Ford, Ponytail, Chubby, Luke and Old George, wait as The Postman steps up before them. Abby's off to the side.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is this everybody?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The rest are on the overdue list.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is everybody. (for all) Got a letter from President Starkey. An excited murmur among the carriers. Only Ford eyes The Postman suspiciously. The Postman reads:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 'Greetings all carriers.'
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Greetings, President Starkey!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 'I've been in contact with The Postman. I've received all the reports. I'm proud of you all.' He looks at them, doesn't need to read what's in his heart. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 137   CONTINUED:                                                      137 THE POSTMAN In dark days, in a weary world, you gave everything and asked for nothing. You beat back despair and replaced it with hope and for that your country can never repay you. But the price is too high. I won't see anymore of my bravest die. It is my duty to hereby disband the Postal Service of the restored United States. You are to burn your uniforms and The Postman is to return to Minneapolis at once. Thank you and that is all. A hushed silence. The Postman walks away. The carriers exchange tired, defeated looks. Abby just sighs, knows he's not necessarily wrong. Ford catches up with The Postman.    He stares at The Postman; The Postman stares back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The President never wrote that letter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If he could've that's what he would have said. Ford gestures to the second letter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who's the other letter to?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bethlehem. I'm taking it to him in the morning.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What does it say?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mail's private. You know that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What does it say?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It says it's over. It says we quit. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 137   CONTINUED:    (2)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It says you quit. What about the oath?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tell me something, Ford. How much mail can a dead postman deliver? It's over. The Postman starts to walk away again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then I'll take it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can't trust you. Ford gathers courage and confronts The Postman.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If this is the end. If this is the last piece of mail that ever gets delivered. I'll take it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Whoever takes this letter probably dies for it. Ford thrusts out his hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm still a postman. You owe it to me... I owe it to me. The Postman hesitates, studies the intense young man. Gives him the letter. 138   EXT. R.V. CAMP - STABLE AREA - DAY                               138 The Postman is packing bags onto a horse as Abby approaches.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm going to St. Rose, Abby. And I'm taking you with me. I know you don't want to hear it, but that's my child inside you. I want to see it born somewhere safe. I have a right to that, Abby. Whether you like it or not. Abby walks away. The Postman rests his head on his pack for a moment. Heavy. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 138   CONTINUED:                                                       138 The CLICK of a GUN causes The Postman to lift his head and see Luke standing there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thought I recognized you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: General Bethlehem said... (raises the pistol) ... You should be on your knees when I do it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't give a damn what that asshole said.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The general is a great man.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The general is a fucking lunatic. The Postman steps forward. Stops when the barrel of the pistol is right against his own chest.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You don't own a thought in that goddamn head of yours, do you? (a beat) You want to see a man? The Postman turns to watch as Ford starts out of camp.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's a man. The Postman turns, sees Luke's face fraught with confusion and emotion.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You don't understand, do you? You never will until you can think for yourself and be willing to pay the price for it. Luke stares back into The Postman's eyes.      A frozen beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You ready?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 138   CONTINUED:    (2)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Abby sits on her horse. She's witness to it all. Luke is confused and ashamed. The Postman mounts his horse and moves to Abby's side.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're a better man than Bethlehem, Luke. I've seen it. 139   EXT. RIDGE - R.V. CAMP - DAY                                    139 Some carriers drop their uniforms into a bonfire. The Postman and Abby ride up on the ridge above the RV camp. They pause to look back one last time. Across the way, on the other side, Ford is doing the same thing. As though he senses it, Ford stops and looks back. Ford raises his hand, salutes. Slowly, The Postman brings up his own hand. But he doesn't salute. He waves. Good- bye. As Ford turns away, so does The Postman. ON CHUBBY, PONYTAIL AND CARRIER NAMED DREW watching as The Postman and Abby disappear from sight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Guess Minneapolis is that way. 140   EXT. INTERSTATE - DAY                                           140 A sign prohibits pedestrians, horses and bicycles. The Postman and Abby ride by. The Postman no longer wears his uniform. Their gear is packed behind their saddles. As a family of transients begin to rise from where they're camped in the breakdown lane:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We can't help you. We're just as lost as you are. The Postman rides on. Abby watches over her shoulder as they slowly begin to sit back down. 141   EXT. HOLNIST CAMP - BETHLEHEM'S TENT - DAWN                     141 Bethlehem sits waiting at his camp table.     Behind him, a finished painting. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 141   CONTINUED:                                                        141 This time he's painted himself in the grand Rococo-style - - as part of the Holy Family with doves and flowers and glowing rays from Heaven. It's awful. Getty and Gibbs bring in a prisoner.       It's Ford!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good lord, what do we have here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm a representative of the restored United States -- Bethlehem backhands Ford.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's got a letter. Says The Postman sent it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A letter? Bethlehem tears open the letter and starts to read:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 'Bethlehem. This letter is my testimony to the fact that there is no restored United States and there is no Postal Service.' (laugh; grim) Then who the hell have we been fighting...? (reads on) 'My carriers are returning home. In exchange, I'm asking you to let them be. The Postman.' Bethlehem eyes Ford with undisguised contempt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He expects me to believe this?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's true, sir. I was there. He disbanded the carriers and rode west. Ford turns blazing eyes to Luke -- he's been standing there all along.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Traitor... It takes a moment for the news to sink in.      But it does. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 141   CONTINUED:    (2)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then I've won.     I've won. As the assembled Holnists congratulate each other, Bethlehem looks at Luke.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You were supposed to kill him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I couldn't get close enough. (re: Ford) This one's his second in command. Bethlehem looks Ford over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why doesn't that surprise me? Ford stares back.    Proud.     Bethlehem looks to Getty.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bring out the one we found yesterday. They can die together. A frightened CARRIER is brought up. He wears a purple uniform with CALI sewn on the shoulder. Neither we nor Ford have seen him before. As a firing squad assembles, Ford is shoved over with him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who are you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Name's Clark. Postal Carrier of the restored Republic of California. Who are you? Ford looks at him a second, can't help but laugh.      From Gibbs; the shout of "ready!"
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Postmaster Ford Lincoln Mercury.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's an honor. Bethlehem watches as Clark holds out his hand.      Ford shakes it. "Aim!"
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wait a minute... wait a minute! (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 141   CONTINUED:    (3)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sir?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hold your fire! You don't know each other? (to himself, quiet anger building) This will never be over. It'll go on except I'll be fighting a goddamn ghost.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Should we fire, sir?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No goddamnit. Bethlehem crumples the letter, tosses it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, I won't fight a ghost. Tabula rasa, gentlemen. A clean slate. I want all mail carriers hunted down. I want The Postman found. I want him dealt with. (to Getty) Colonel, organize the scouts. (to Luke) He rode west? 142   EXT. RIVER - DAY                                             142 A pair of boots are walking through the water. It's The Postman. He turns over a body in the water. It wears a homemade postal uniform, a bag of mail twisted around his arm. It's a young face, one we haven't seen before. He looks up to Abby on a ridge.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know him. Do you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where do you think he came from? Puzzled, The Postman shakes his head. He gently releases the body. The current takes it and they watch as it continues on its way to Postal Valhalla. 143   EXT. INTERSTATE - DAY                                        143 The family of transients are grilled by three Holnist scouts. One man points the way Abby and Bethlehem rode.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 144   EXT. PLAIN - DAY                                                  144 Littered with rubble. The wood, brick, steel and concrete of what was once a small town. Amazingly, one gray house still stands, miraculously untouched by whatever disaster visited this place. A wild-haired SQUATTER steps out on the porch as Abby and The Postman ride by. He waves hello with a .45.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Howdy. Welcome to sunny California.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What happened here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Little accident. The ground started to shake big time and the Hanford nuclear plant went... (motions an explosion) ... 'Poof.' Destroyed everything for miles. But the sunsets are beautiful.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You ever hear of a city called St. Rose?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Friend, I've never heard of St. Shit. The Squatter laughs and laughs -- like it was the funniest thing in the world. The Postman and Abby exchange a look, continue on their way.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey, don't go! I got Monopoly in the house! Boardwalk, Park Place and the Reading Railroad!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 145   EXT. EDGE OF RUBBLE - DAY                                         145 Ponytail, Chubby, and Draw watching from afar.    Chubby has the telescope.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You think that's President Starkey? (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 145   CONTINUED:                                                        145 Ponytail takes the telescope from Chubby for a look.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What makes you so sure?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: President lives in a white house. That guy's place is gray. Drew and Chubby exchange a look.       That makes sense. 146   EXT. SKY - DAY                                                    146 A lightning bolt shreds the sky.       It's day, but the sky is black with rain. 147   EXT. HIGH TENSION TOWERS - DAY                                    147 The useless towers cutting across a valley.      Rain beats down, as The Postman and Abby trudge along. Up ahead, a rail-road tunnel promises shelter from the storm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We can rest in there. Abby is quick to agree. Out of the corner of his eye, The Postman catches a blur of movement. He turns his head quickly, but he's barely in time to see a wooden basket, attached to one of the high wires, swing from a distant tower. There's a sentry inside it. The basketed sentry whistles away at 40 mph, heading straight for an adjacent tower. In a matter of seconds, he's lost from view. The Postman looks back at Abby.       She's shivering.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did you see that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm hungry, Postman. The Postman guides her toward the train tunnel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 148   INT. TRAIN TUNNEL - DAY                                        148 Abby sleeps beside the fire. The Postman, silhouetted against the flames, heads toward the far tunnel exit. 149   EXT. FAR SIDE OF TUNNEL - DAY                                  149 The Postman peers into the rain, taking in the view of a distant bridge. Abby comes to stand at his side. 150   EXT. COLUMBIA RIVER GORGE (BRIDGE CITY) - DAY                  150 A town settled between spans of a steel truss bridge. The Columbia River rushes far below. A sentry spots Abby and The Postman approaching, blows a whistle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Set the rifle on the ground.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This old thing? It isn't even loaded. Where are we? The BRIDGE CITY MAYOR, a middle-aged retro-hippie, steps up. B.C. MAYOR You're in Bridge City. Where we don't allow guns. The Postman sets down the carbine.    The Guard steps over to scoop it up. B.C. MAYOR Sentry said you were coming. The Postman stares at the Mayor a beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know you.     You're famous. B.C. MAYOR I was once. Not anymore. (beat) Are you looking to cross?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We will be. Right now, we'd just appreciate some food. (as the Mayor nods his assent) I got some kids behind me, too. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 150   CONTINUED:                                                       150 B.C. MAYOR How many?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Three. (as the Mayor agrees once more) Hey, guys, come on in! I know you're out there!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Boy, is he smart... As they stand, show themselves. 151   EXT. NORTH BOUND LANE (BRIDGE CITY) - DUSK                       151 Fog rolls in.    Abby rests. Ponytail, Chubby and Drew look up gratefully as one of the citizens of Bridge City doles out bread. The Mayor steps over, hands The Postman two loaves. B.C. MAYOR For you and your wife.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thanks.    She's not my wife. The exchange cuts Abby like a knife. She gets up and leaves. The Mayor keeps his council -- not sure what to make of this arrangement.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let me ask you something, have you ever heard of a town with electric lights? B.C. MAYOR St. Rose?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah! B.C. MAYOR Never been. But they say it's a ways down on the coast.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How far? (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 151   CONTINUED:                                                       151 B.C. MAYOR Couple hundred miles at least.   I couldn't say for sure. It's the discovery of a lifetime. The Postman looks to the west end of the bridge, where Abby stands alone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You seem like a decent man. And these seem like decent people. B.C. MAYOR We try to be.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And this seems like a safe place. B.C. MAYOR (intuitive) You want to leave her? The Postman looks back to the Mayor, then slowly nods.
direction.name: direction
