direction.raw_text: All of them. I'll give you the horses and my gear. Abby's special. She's strong. Probably end up running the place. B.C. MAYOR Why don't you take the night to think. Decide if that's what you really want. 152   EXT. BRIDGE - NIGHT                                              152 Fog obscures the east end. A sentry squints at the MUFFLED CLOP of HOOVES. The mist parts to reveal, seventy yards away: three Holnist scouts on horseback. Emissaries from hell. As the sentry blows a whistle... BRIDGE As word spreads, folks move down the bridge for a look. Eating their bread, The Postman, Abby and the carriers join them. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 152   CONTINUED:                                                     152 EAST END The Mayor stands across from the lead scout -- conferring. Finally, the Mayor points him back the way he came. The lead scout doesn't budge, spots The Postman in the crowd. He and The Postman seem to stare at each other forever. Then, with a flick of the reins, he's gone. The other two follow. Swallowed up by the misty evening gloom. The Postman's head swims dizzily. It's not over. The Mayor returns to dozens of nervous questions. B.C. MAYOR They're looking for The Postman. B.C. MAN No such thing anymore. B.C. MAYOR Man on the horse says there is. Says he thinks he's here. Says he's coming back with friends. A little BOY steps forward, sings out. B.C. BOY What's a postman? A silent moment. It's been so long, no one's sure how to answer. The Postman looks down at the ground. The carriers exchange deflated looks. Then...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You never heard of a postman? He shakes his head "no." Seems a shame. As The Postman looks over at Abby, she takes a page from his book.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There used to be a postman for every street in America. They wore uniforms. And hats. Like this one... She goes to The Postman's gear, returns with his postal cap. Sets it on the boy's head. B.C. BOY Wow... (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 152   CONTINUED:    (2)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My postman knew the name of every kid on my street. He knew our birthdays. He'd even find the baseballs you'd hit down the street. I can still see the smile on his face. The tip of his cap
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: when he had a letter in his bag with my name on it. Mine always came just after school. You could set your watch by him. Unless you were waiting on something special
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: like a present from somewhere far away or a letter from your sweetheart. Then it seemed like he'd never come. I used to think they could make time stand still. Several other listeners nod -- they're completely with her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't think we ever really understood what they meant to us until they were gone. Getting a letter made you feel like you were part of something bigger than yourself. No place was ever too far away for the postman. So nobody ever had to be alone. The postman was someone you could count on. Things just made more sense when they were around. (beat) That's the kind of world we used to have. A world a lot of us took for granted. And now we've got this one. And it makes me wonder -- what kind of world do I want my child to live in? I want my child to live in a world where hopes and dreams aren't just lies you tell yourself to get through another day. I want my child, and I want my friends -- I want all of us to live in a world where you still get your mail. It's a   moment before anyone speaks. B.C. MAYOR (to The Postman) Are you The Postman? (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 152   CONTINUED:    (3)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Postman takes the cap off the little boy's head, touches the emblem, and answers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. B.C. MAYOR I've heard of you, man. You're famous.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, I guess I am. And all of a sudden, I'm not wearing the right clothes. And as he puts on his cap, he accepts the mantle as well. 153   EXT. BRIDGE - CLOSE ON PINE BOX - MORNING                       153 lowered from the top of the bridge. Hands reach up to steady it and bring it gently to the ground. It's one of many. The Postman and Abby gasp as the Mayor opens the lid to reveal: 20 well-oiled rifles and 15 pistols with ammo. The Postman blinks over at the Mayor. B.C. MAYOR Fact that we don't allow 'em doesn't mean we don't have 'em. We're not stupid, after all.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry I've brought this on you. B.C. MAYOR No need to be sorry. Long as we get our mail on time.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ready for duty, sir. The Postman looks over to see Ponytail, Drew and Chubby ride up. Like him, they are back in uniform.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The order was to burn all uniforms. The carriers look away -- sheepish. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 153   CONTINUED:                                                         153 THE POSTMAN You know what to do then?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Talk to the people. Gather who's willing. Tell them it's important. Tell them we can make a difference.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And tell 'em we're going to kick ass.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, tell them that, too. 154   EXT. NEAR BRIDGE - DAY                                             154 At the edge of the Gorge. The three carriers, and the mounted locals thunder off the bridge and down the road. High above... 155   EXT. HIGH TENSION TOWER - POSTMAN AND ABBY                         155 The Mayor is in the b.g. helping one of the sentries prepare the basket for travel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is hard for me. (beat) Michael was the best man I ever knew. I never thought there'd be another man I could love the way I loved him. (searching for the words) I don't know why I've been so blessed. And I've tried to find a way to be thankful, but I swear, if I lose you... Her eyes start to tear and he takes her in his arms.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Abby, do you think a lie can become the truth?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know, but I believe in you. You have a gift, Postman.     I saw it back in Pine View. (MORE) (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 155   CONTINUED:                                                       155 ABBY (CONT'D) You made Mrs. March feel like she could see again. You made Ford feel like he was part of the world. You give out hope like it was candy in your pocket. He starts to speak.    She stops him, taking his hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When you come back, we'll be waiting here for you. So you can take us to St. Rose. The Postman lets go of her hand and starts for the basket. The Mayor gestures to the line of towers extending into the distance. B.C. MAYOR There's three good-sized towns up that way. Enough folks to be a big help to you. If you can convince them to come. As The Postman steps into the basket, he makes the mistake of looking over the edge. It's a long, long way down. B.C. MAYOR A lot higher than it looks, huh? The Postman looks at the contraption with more than a little trepidation. The Mayor grins. B.C. MAYOR Don't tell anybody, but I like to ride the damn thing just for the hell of it. Being a city official has its perks. He winks and as he reaches for the release pin.     The Postman's hand meets his there. B.C. MAYOR Trust me, man. This'll get you there a lot faster.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How do I stop -- But it's too late.    The Mayor releases the pin. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 155   CONTINUED:    (2)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't worry about it. Good luck and Godspeed. COUNTERWEIGHT Plummeting into the Columbia River Gorge.      The Mayor lets out a rebel yell. BASKET The Postman is whipped along, past the riders below.     The speed exhilarating. 156   EXT. PINE VIEW, OREGON - DAY                                     156 The town's gone, but the palisade remains. Chubby rides along it, exhorting the people who watch from above. But it's The Postman we hear, all the magic back in his voice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Once more into the breach, dear friends, once more. Or close the wall with our dead. In peace nothing so becomes a man as modesty and humility. But when the blast of war blows in our ears, then imitate the action of the tiger. 157   EXT. ELVIS, OREGON - NIGHT                                       157 A few makeshift structures are back up. Carrying a torch, Ponytail gallops hard into town. People wake, including Mrs. March's daughter. As Ponytail speaks to them...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Summon up the blood. Disguise fair nature with rage and lend the eye a terrible aspect. 158   EXT. FIELD - DAY                                                 158 Captured by a Holnist cavalry patrol, Old George and four other carriers are lined up, hands bound before them. Holnist soldiers force them to their knees as Gibbs organizes an impromptu firing squad. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 158   CONTINUED:                                                       158 Old George looks down the line.    The carriers are about to break down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Steady, boys, steady. And as Gibbs steps up, all hope is gone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In accordance with Law Eight...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Get on with it, you floppy-eared sonuvabitch! We see the faces of the young carriers. Defeated, bitter. But there's a sudden spark in Old George's eyes. He starts to rise. The soldiers pick up their guns and that's when they see The Postman. THE POSTMAN Riding over the crest. Galloping toward them. Behind him, forty new mail carriers. All riding like mad. One of them carries the flag of the restored United States. Gibbs and his men run for their horses. SHOTS are FIRED. Four Holnists go down. The rest gallop away. The Postman and his carriers meet. 159   EXT. CROSSROADS - DAY                                            159 Converging. The Postman with his forty-five coming from the west. Drew, Chubby, and a ragtag thirty coming from the north. And from the south, Ponytail leading a contingent of fifty! The forces converge and continue east. 160   EXT. HOLNIST CAMP - DAY                                          160 The army has gathered.    Three hundred strong. Bethlehem and Getty stand outside the command tent, listening to a winded, frightened Gibbs. We FOLLOW Bethlehem's eyes OVER Gibbs' SHOULDERS TO the horizon, where he sees: The Postman and his army of two hundred carriers cresting a distant rise. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 160   CONTINUED:                                                     160 GIBBS (O.S.) ... We were outnumbered, sir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How many?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A least a hundred. With guns.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With guns? Are you sure?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, sir...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Looks more like two hundred to me... He steps away to get a better vantage point of the approaching army. He reaches out -- Getty hands him a pair of binoculars.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Only thing worse than a coward is one who can't count. Lieutenant, do yourself a favor. Die well in this battle. In my army a deserter's life is a brief and unpleasant one. Bethlehem watches The Postman through the binoculars -- a hint of a smile on his face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: At last, someone with courage enough to bring the fight to me. A Holnist soldier stands by with Bethlehem's horse.   The General mounts -- the model of military calm and precision. Getty reins up beside him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Reckoning, gentlemen. This is the day I've dreamed of. 161   EXT. BATTLEFIELD - DAY                                         161 A sea of wildflowers separates the carriers from the Holnists. The monster John Deere gun is ready for battle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 162   EXT. HOLNIST LINE - DAY                                        162 Bethlehem stands with Getty, scanning the postal line with his binoculars. The carriers look, just spoiling for a fight. Bethlehem lowers his binoculars, smiles grimly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They're an eager-looking bunch. Morale's a dangerous thing. (to Getty) Bring him up. I want this postman to see how the game is played. 163   EXT. CARRIERS' LINE - DAY                                      163 The Postman, Chubby, Ponytail and Old George and all the carriers have taken positions. The Postman sights through a telescope. He scans further down the line -- then stops when he sees Ford. Bloody, beaten within inches of his life. He's shackled -- surrounded by Holnist guards. The Postman's eyes turn to stone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stay here. No one moves until I give the orders. He clicks his horse forward, toward the Holnist line. 164   EXT. HOLNIST LINE - DAY                                        164 Bethlehem, flanked by Getty and the Holnist Sergeant, watches as The Postman makes his approach. He reaches into his pocket, withdraws a white kerchief and holds it in the air.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are they surrendering?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: God, I hope not. He watches for a moment as The Postman crosses the field - - moving well within range of Holnist fire. Then, he coaxes his horse forward.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 165   EXT. MEADOW - DAY                                              165 Bethlehem and The Postman riding toward each other. They meet when The Postman is almost three-quarters of the way over to the Holnists' side. BETHLEHEM AND POSTMAN As they come face-to-face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My little shipping clerk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're both a couple of frauds. You know it; I know it. Bethlehem sneers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Great men are made by other great men. Patton had Rommel. Grant had Lee. But I get you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're no fucking   general. You're a copying machine   salesman. You're not even a   good painter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you trying to goad me into a fight?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wouldn't it be great if wars could be fought just by the assholes who started them? We could settle this thing right here. You and me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Unfortunately, it doesn't work that way.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It does in your army. The Postman kicks his horse up into a gallop, and rides up the Holnist line. No one, least of all Bethlehem, is sure what's going on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I invoke law seven of the Laws of Eight! Any man may challenge for leadership of the clan! (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 165   CONTINUED:                                                      165 BETHLEHEM What? The Postman wheels his horse around.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I challenge you. Bethlehem is caught completely by surprise, but recovers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're not a Holnist. You're not a member of the clan. You don't have the right. The Postman rolls up his sleeve. He rides the Holnist lines displaying his brand for all to see. The Holnists murmur amongst themselves.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have every right. I invoke law seven! Bethlehem can't believe his eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I challenge for leadership of the clan! The seed of doubt is planted. Is Bethlehem violating one of the Laws of Eight? The men look at one another. Gibbs looks to Getty. Bethlehem looks from The Postman's tattoo to his face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where do I know you from?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 'Cry Havoc! And let slip the dogs of war.' Remember that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shakespeare. The one who didn't want to fight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I should've found a way to kill you then. But you seemed so strong.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Law seven it is. (to all) This war is settled here! (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 165   CONTINUED:    (2)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As The Postman nods in agreement. They take their positions -- and without a word -- they kick their horses into a charge. Coming straight for each other like medieval jousters. Bethlehem reaches for his sword.    But before it clears the scabbard, The Postman lunges. The horses collide.    Bethlehem and The Postman hit the ground hard. Holnists and Carriers alike begin to move forward for a better look. The fight is fierce. Bloody. The Postman and Bethlehem are at each other like coiled snakes. It's more of a fight than any of the Holnists -- especially Getty -- expected. The spectators pull in tighter. Both combatants have taken a beating -- and still, they fight on -- trading bloody, raw-knuckled punches. One of Bethlehem's connects. The Postman loses his footing, hits the ground -- knocking his head on a rock with a resounding CRACK. Dazed, he's slow to rise. It's just the moment Bethlehem needs, he straddles the fallen Postman, reaches for his knife with one hand -- grabs The Postman's throat with the other.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I study people. I know your problem. Do you know why you can't fight? The Postman can't answer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You have nothing to fight for. You don't care about anything. You don't value anything. You don't believe in anything. That's what makes me better. The Postman grabs Bethlehem's knife-hand -- using all his remaining strength to keep him at bay.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I believe in the United States Postal Service. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 165   CONTINUED:    (3)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Postman lets go of Bethlehem's hands, grabs his belt and pulls him over. As they roll to their feet, The Postman club-fists Bethlehem on the side of the head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Neither snow... (wham!) Nor rain... (wham!) Nor heat... (wham!) Nor gloom of night... (wham!) Will stay this courier from the swift completion of his appointed rounds... Bethlehem reels, stumbling back. The Postman pounces on top of him, begins to strangle him. Bethlehem tries to pry the fingers from his throat, but can't. He's going to die. The Postman is urged on. By both sides. Holnists. Carriers. Ford. Even Holnist Luke. He looks up at the faces -- and finally lets Bethlehem go. The General gasps for breath. As Ponytail and Chubby move forward to untie Ford, The Postman looks to both sides.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It doesn't have to be this way. We don't have to kill each other. We can live together. We can -- Ford takes Chubby's pistol, sets it against the side of Bethlehem's head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Law three.   Mercy is for the weak.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ford, don't... Bethlehem shakes his head -- doesn't want him to, either.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Law eight. There is only one penalty and that penalty is death. Ford's going to shoot. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 165   CONTINUED:    (4)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He isn't worth it. I'm the head of the clan now! There are going to be new laws! (to all) Law one! No more killing! There's going to be peace! The Postman looks at carriers and Holnists alike.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who else?   Who else has a law?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Everyone has to learn how to read.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's law two. Who else?!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Three.    Liberty and justice for all!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Four.    No more tattoos.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Law five.   Give peace a chance!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Law six. Mercy is, it's okay sometimes!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Seven!    Bring back vacations! The Postman nods solemnly, looks to Ford.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How about it, Ford Lincoln Mercury? You give us law eight. Ford grits his teeth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Be a leader, Ford.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Law eight... Ford FIRES! Bethlehem flinches, then sags as he realizes Ford has fired into the ground. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 165   CONTINUED:    (5)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... Live and let live. The Postman smiles in relief as Ford lowers the revolver and starts to hand the weapon over. Forgotten for an instant, Bethlehem makes a last, wild lunge, grabs Ford's gun. As Bethlehem aims at The Postman, a SHOT rings out. Hit in the chest, Bethlehem blinks in amazement before he falls to the ground, dying. Getty has shot him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Would I had bestowed that time in the tongues that I have in fencing, dancing and bear-baiting. Oh, had I but followed the arts... He dies.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Grow like savages -- as soldiers will -- that nothing do but mediate on blood. Getty throws his rifle on the ground. Other weapons are laid down. The war, at long last, is over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Somebody take a letter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Huh?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A letter...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : 166   INT. ABBY'S PLACE (BRIDGE CITY) - DAY                            166 Abby, in bed, holding her new baby in her arms. She's reading a letter. What she reads makes her smile. She puts the letter down and cuddles her baby.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your daddy wrote to tell you that he'll be here as soon as he can. And that he loves you very much. Abby looks up to see The Postman standing at her door. She looks at him, smiling with tears in her eyes. (CONTINUED)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . 166   CONTINUED:                                                         166 THE POSTMAN Mail's slow.   I'll have to see about that. Abby smiles down at the child in her arms.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your daughter.     Her name is Hope. The Postman takes the tiny child in his arms.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And so my father returned home after the Holnists were defeated... 167   EXT. ST. ROSE - DAY                                                167 A beach town. No wall, no sentries, just cottages lining a dozen sand-swept streets. A crowd has gathered to hear The Postman's daughter, HOPE, mid-thirties, speak. Beside her, a bearded, 52-year-old Ford in his postmaster's uniform. They stand before a large, tarp-draped statue.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But he never did see St. Rose. There was too much to be done. He'd made a promise and in keeping it -- he traded one dream for another. With no regrets. And so, in honor of my father... She unveils the statue: we've seen this before. It's The Postman on his horse, low-slung in the saddle, leaning down to pluck the letter from the Little Boy's hand. There's an OLDER MAN in the audience who seems especially moved by the statue. There's a younger man beside him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That was me. As St. Rose applauds...
direction.name: direction

result.heading: EXT.
location: ON POSTMAN AND CARRIERS 128 THE POSTMAN

result.heading: ON CHUBBY, PONYTAIL AND CARRIER NAMED DREW
